metadata.title: Properties of nano silica modified rubbercrete

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Cleaner Production
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jc lepro
Properties of nano silica modified rubbercrete
Bashar S. Mohammed*, Azinda Binti Awang, San San Wong, Calibio Paulino Nhavene Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, 32610 Bandar Seri Iskandar, Perak Darul Ridzuan, Malaysia
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 28 September 2015 Received in revised form 25 January 2016 Accepted 1 February 2016 Available online xxx
Keywords: Rubbercrete Nano silica ITZ MIP Impact resistance Compressive strength
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: bashar.mohammed@petronas.com
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007 0959-6526/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article in press as: Mohamm http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.0
a b s t r a c t
Inclusion of crumb rubber from scrap tires in concrete as partial replacement to fine aggregate in production of rubbercrete has provided many beneficial impacts to both environments and concrete. Many properties of rubbercrete are improved compared with conventional concrete. However, drawbacks such as reduction in rubbercrete strengths have limited the application of rubbercrete drastically. Therefore, this paper presents a new method on producing rubbercrete with comparable compressive strength to the reference mixture (0% of crumb rubber) by adding nano silica. Twenty four mixtures, with four levels (0%, 10%, 25% and 50%) of crumb rubber replacement to fine aggregate by volume and six levels of nano silica addition (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 4% and 5%), were prepared and tested. The microstructure of these mixtures is also investigated and analyzed. It has been found that the inclusion of nano silica would refine the size of the pores and densify the interfacial transition zone between cement matrix and aggregate in hardened rubbercrete. This has resulted rubbercrete with fair compressive strength compared to conventional concrete.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Massive volume of scrap tires are being discarded annually with average of 250, 10 and 3.4 million tons in United State, Turkey and European Union, respectively (Demir et al., 2015; Onuaguluchi and Panesar, 2014). Globally, more than 500 million units of waste tires were being discarded without any treatment each year after the end of their service life (Thomas et al., 2016). This increasing numbers has raised concern worldwide due to the threat it poses directly and indirectly to the human health, safety and the preservation of the environment. The deposition of scrap tires in landfills and dumpsites serve as a breeding ground to pests and vermin. In addition, these scrap tires are scarcely biodegradable in nature over time and poses a haze danger in case of fire (Pelisser et al., 2011). Hence, recycling of scrap tires as crumb rubbers (CR) in concrete has become one of alternatives in sustaining the ecological balance with also an added value of economic significant (Guo et al., 2014).
CR from outer part of scrap tires is used as partial replacement to fine aggregates in Portland cement concrete and the concrete produces from this replacement is known as rubberized concrete, crumb rubber concrete or rubbercrete. Rubbercrete exhibits
.my (B.S. Mohammed).
ed, B.S., et al., Properties of na 07
numerous benefits compared to conventional concrete such as lower density (Demir et al., 2015), increased ductility (Shu and Huang, 2014), enhanced plastic capacity (Mohammed et al., 2011), higher toughness (Mohammed, 2010), higher impact resistance (Ganjian et al., 2009), better resistance to chloride penetration (Bravo and Brito, 2012), lower thermal conductivity (Mohammed et al., 2012), higher noise reduction factor (Li et al., 2004b) and better electrical resistivity (Onuaguluchi and Panesar, 2014). It has also been known to have better energy dissipation, durability and damping ratio (Youssf et al., 2014).
However, the main drawbacks of rubbercrete are decreasing in strengths (compressive, flexural, tensile and splitting) and Young's modulus as the partial replacement of CR to fine aggregate increased. The lower strength of rubbercrete is due to the weak bonding between cement matrix and the CR particles. This is attributed to the hydrophobic properties of CR due to the zinc stearate application during tires manufacturing (Youssf et al., 2014). The non-polar layer of CR repels water and traps air around it leading to increasing thickness of the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) between the CR and cement matrix, resulting in weak bond (Onuaguluchi and Panesar, 2014; Mohammed et al., 2012). Stress concentration on this weak bond causes formation of micro cracks hence leading to premature failure (Thomas et al., 2016; Mohammed et al., 2012; Li et al., 2016; Sadek and El-Attar, 2015).
Thus, to widen the practical application of rubbercrete and increasing its acceptability in the construction industry, it is essential
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),
to enhance its strengths. Therefore, to produce rubbercrete with higherstrengths, researchershave tried to improve thebondbetween CR and cementmatrix through several surface treatmentmethods to CR particles. Rostami et al. (1993) treated the surface of the CR and results showed that surface treatment using water, carbon tetrachloride solvent, and latex admixture cleaner increased the compressive strength by 16%, 42% and 57%; respectively compared to control mix. Li et al. (1998) pre-coated the CRwith cement paste and METHOCEL cellulose ether solution. They reported that the strength of rubbercrete was slightly improved using cement paste's precoating whilst the ether solution reduced the strength of rubbercrete. Segre and Joekes (2000) reported that CR surface treatment using aqueousNaOHhas enhanced the bond between cementmatrix and CR hence resulted higher strengths. Albano et al. (2005) have partially replaced the fine aggregate in concrete with CR pre-treated with NaOH and silane A-174 coupling agent by weight proportion to observe the effect of the treatment on themechanical properties of rubbercrete. They found that neither treatments using NaOH nor silane coupling agent succeed to increase the mechanical strength of the rubbercrete. Gesoglu and Guneyisi (2007) have studied the effect of inclusion 10% silica fume as partial replacement of cement on the performance of rubbercrete. Their findings indicated that silica fume enhanced the strength and chloride penetration resistance of the rubbercrete through formation of stronger bond between CR and cementmatrix.Yet, the strengthof the rubbercretewasrecorded tobe lower than the controlmix. Balaha et al. (2007) investigated the effect of using 10% concentrated NaOH, polyvinyl acetate (PVA) and 15% silica fume in the rubbercrete mixtures. The NaOH, PVA and silica fume were observed to increase the strength of rubbercrete compared to the non-treated mixtures with slightly similar percentages of reduction: 14%, 15% and 17%, respectively. Chou et al. (2010a) treated the CR with organic sulfur to promote the production of hydrophilic group on the surface of the CR. They observed that treated CR increased the strength of rubbercrete. Next, Chou et al. (2010b) studied the effect of partial oxidation of CR on the strengths of rubbercrete. With manipulation of temperature, the oxidation process promotes the production of hydrophilic group on the surface of CRwhich led to stronger bondwith cementmatrix and resulted in higher strengthof rubbercrete.However, thismethod is economically unviable for construction application as the end product would be costly. Pelisser et al. (2011) used NaOH and 15% silica fume by mass fraction to enhance the strength of the rubbercrete. They reported that CR treated with NaOH and rubbercrete incorporated with silica fume has lower percentage of strength reduction compared to rubbercrete without silica fume. Corinaldesi et al. (2011) have investigated the performance of rubbercrete containing limestone powder as filler and an acrylic-based superplasticizer admixture. They observed that bothmaterials reduced the porosity of the rubbercrete thus increased its strengthcomparable to the referencemixture.Turki et al. (2012) also reported an enhancement in strength of the rubbercrete with 5% replacement of cement with silica fume and limestone powder in rubbercretemixture. Nevertheless, the strengthwas observed tobe lower thanof the conventional concrete. Azevedoet al. (2012) utilized fly ash and metakaolin as a cement replacement in rubbercrete to improve its strengths.Althoughflyashandmetakaolin has different hydration rate, the result shows a synergy between fly ash andmetakaolin in enhancing the strengths of rubbercrete. Huang et al. (2013) and Dong et al. (2013) employed two stage surface treatments on theCRbyusing silane couplingagent and cementitious coating. Treatmentwith silane coupling agentwasefficient ingaining the strength of rubbercrete while execution of both stages of surface treatment were observed to be more effective compared to single stage application. Meddah et al. (2014) treated the surface of the CR with NaOH and glued fine aggregate to the CR to increase roughness of the CR's surface. However, they concluded that the treatment
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
method is ineffective in improving the strength of the rubbercrete. OnuaguluchiandPanesar (2014) investigated theeffectofpre-coating of the CR with limestone powder and addition of silica fume to the cement of the rubbercretemixtures. Rubbercretewith coated CR and silica fume addition exhibited an increase in strength up to 29% compared to the control mix. This increment was linked to the positive interactionbetween the limestonepowder and silica fumewhich enhanced the bond between CR and cement matrix. Thomas and Gupta (2015) studied the effect of partially replacing fine aggregate within rubbercretewith threedifferent sizesofCR. They reported that the strengths and the resistance of rubbercrete to sulfate attack were lower than the controlmix. On recent note, Li et al. (2016) treated the waste tire fiber in rubbercrete with silane coupling agent and carboxylated styrene-butadiene rubber latex. The treatment was observed to enhance the bond between CR and cement matrix, thus increase the compressive and flexural strength of the rubbercrete compared to the reference mix by 4% and 13% respectively.
However, Dong et al. (2013) and Shu and Huang (2014) have indicated that, methods of CR treatments exhibited insignificant effect on enhancing strengths of rubbercrete comparable to conventional concrete. Therefore, the application of rubbercrete in the construction industry is too limited due to its uncompetitive strength compared to other types of concrete.
On the other hand, emerging developments in nano technology exhibits a convincing future in the advancement of material at nano scale. Nano technology has allowed the manipulation of matters at the atomic level, thus enabling researchers to control the properties of the outcome product. Nano-engineered materials are proven to have higher performance compared to their large-scale counterpart due to their nano sizes. In construction industry, the novelty of nano silica through this technology has provided solution for the demands of high performance material with competent product end-cost (Mukharjee and Barai, 2014b). Studies have shown that nano silica has the ability to improve the strength of concrete. Its large area-to-volume ratio gives advantage to nano silica to act as physical filler in filling nano voids between larger particles within cement aggregates (Abd.El.Aleem et al., 2014). It also acts as an activator to Pozzolanic reaction, which further produces more CeSeH gel leading to enhancing the microstructure of concrete (Nili and Ehsani, 2015; Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a). In addition, nano silica leads to reduction of capillary porosity and reduces permeability of concrete due to the blockage effect of nano silica (Du et al., 2014). Nano silica also helps in densifying the ITZ between aggregates and cement matrix which leads to better bond and consequently enhancing the strengths of the concrete (Mukharjee and Barai, 2014c). Therefore, the main objective of the researchwork reported in this paper is to investigate the properties of rubbercrete containing nano silica.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Materials used in preparations of dry rubbercrete mixtures were ordinary Portland cement, fly ash (F), river sand (fine aggregate: FA), nano silica (NS), mineral coarse aggregates (CA) with the maximum nominal size of 10 mm, crumb rubber (CR) and potable water. The chemical compositions of the cementitious/pozzolanic materials are shown in Table 1. The ordinary Portland cement (OPC) is type 1 conforming to the requirements of ASTM. The fly ash was classified as class F with total amount of silicon oxide (SiO2), aluminum oxide (Al2O3) and iron oxide (Fe2O3) of 88.48% and loss of ignition less than 6% according to the specification of ASTM C618 (American Society for Testing and Materials, 2005).
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),
The physical properties of coarse aggregate (10 maximum nominal size), fine aggregate (river sand) and mesh 30 crumb rubber (CR) are shown in Table 2. The CR were resulted from processed of scrap tires prepared through shredding and granulation process consisting of primary and secondary granulation process which then feed into rolling mills. The process reduces scrap tire from 100 mm to 50 mm and smaller through the cracking or grinding process. The steel wires within the scrap tires are separated from the processed tires stage by stage throughout the process.

sections.heading: 2.2. Rubbercrete mixtures proportions
sections.text: This investigation involves of 24 rubbercrete dry mixtures at four levels of CR replacement by volume to fine aggregate (0%, 10%, 25% and 50%) and six levels of nano silica addition (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 4% and 5%). The conventional mixture ratio of 1:2:1 by volume [ratio of: cementitious material: fine aggregates (FA): coarse aggregates (CA)] was adopted in this study. The ratio of the cementitious materials used was 85% of cement and 15% of fly ash. Table 3 show mixtures proportions by ratio for each dry rubbercrete mixture. In Table 3, the mix NS0 CR0 for instance refers to the amount of nano silica addition is 0% and CR replacement to fine aggregate is 0% as well (control mix). The total amount of water content used in this study was 8% of the total batch weight as has been suggested by Mohammed et al. (2012).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of test specimen and test procedure
sections.text: After mixing the ingredients of rubbercrete dry mixture, test samples were prepared by applying mechanical pressure of 2500 MPa for 1 min. Then, samples were kept in curing room until testing at age of 28 days. Five tests were conducted on samples from each mixture as shown in Table 4.

sections.heading: 3.1. Compressive strength
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 1, for each level of NS, the compressive strength of rubbercrete decreases with increasing the percentage of CR replacement as reported throughout the literature (Mohammed et al., 2011, 2012). The reduction of rubbercrete strength is due to
Table 2 Properties of aggregates.
Properties Coarse aggregate Fine aggregate Crumb rubber
Specific gravity 2.67 2.65 0.95 Water absorption (%) 1.10 2.10 e Moisture content, % 0.3 1.3 e Fineness modulus e 2.2 0.92
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
the weak bonding between cement matrix and CR particles. This is attributed to the hydrophobic properties of CR due to the zinc stearate application (Youssf et al., 2014). The non-polar layer of CR repels water and traps air around it leading to increasing thickness of the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) between the CR and cement matrix, resulting in weak bond (Onuaguluchi and Panesar, 2014; Mohammed et al., 2012). During loading application, stress concentration on this weak bond causes formation of micro cracks hence leading to premature failure (Thomas et al., 2016; Mohammed et al., 2012; Li et al., 2016; Sadek and El-Attar, 2015).
The compressive strength of rubbercrete was observed to increase with the addition of nano silica into the rubbercrete mixtures as shown in Fig. 1. This is attributed to the physico-chemical effects of nano silica in improving the microstructure of the rubbercrete mixture. Whereas the chemical effect is due to ability of the nano silica in reacting with Ca(OH)2 released due to the hydration of cement paste resulting in more production of CeSeH gel which fill up the voids within cement matrix and densify the interfacial transition zone between the cement matrix and aggregates (including CR). Whereas the physical effects are attributed to the ability of nano silica particles in filling up the nano voids in the hardened cement paste and consequently produce denser matrix. In addition, using nano silica would facilitate the use of fly ash by maintaining early strength as reported by others (Abd.El.Aleem et al., 2014; Nili and Ehsani, 2015; Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a).
To examine the compressive strength enhancement as the NS% increasing from 0% to 5% while the CR replacement for all mixtures was kept constant at 10%, Fig. 2 has been presented. As shown in Fig. 2, the compressive strength of rubbercrete increases as the amount of nano silica increases. Adding 1% of nano silica into the rubbercrete mixture leads to improving its compressive strength significantly by 48.5% compared to the reference mixture (NS 0%). This is attributed by the benefits of nano silica in the rubbercrete mixture as aforementioned. As the quantity of nano silica is increased from 1% to 3%, rather small growth in the strength of rubbercrete can be observed. This condition hypothetically is due to insufficient amount of nano silica to fully react with the free
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),

portlandite. Hence, the productions of extra CeSeH gel for the build-up of strength in the rubbercrete is minor while the most of nano silica has been used in filling up the nano voids. As the amount of nano silica in the rubbercrete mixture is increased to more than 3%, the compressive strength drastically rises. However, further increasing the NS percentage to 5% has less effect in improving the strength of the rubbercrete. This observation might be due to agglomeration of NS in the cement matrix (Nili and Ehsani, 2015). This minor increment in strength might be also caused by all the portlandite had fully reacted with the nano silica; causing the increase in the amount of nano silica does not yield any significant increment in the compressive strength (Givi et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 3.2. Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM)
sections.text:
In reality, conventional concrete has three faces of materials which are: the coarse aggregate, matrix (hardened cement paste) and interfacial transition zone (ITZ). The ITZ is a porous phase causing less bonding between cement paste and aggregate, consequently reduces strength. The porosity of the ITZ is attributed
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
to thewall effect, inwhich, the cement particles at the border of the aggregate restrain the water movement and after hydration, the porosity of the ITZ is formed. The ITZ, however, is affected by many factors such as: waterecement ratio, aggregate texture and aggregate size distribution. As the main interest of this study was to investigate the effect of nano silica inclusion on rubbercrete mixtures, the afore-mentioned factors were kept constant. Unlike the conventional concrete, rubbercrete has two ITZs with different natures which are; firstly, ITZ between coarse aggregate and matrix, secondly, ITZ between CR particles and matrix. This would justify the high reduction in the compressive strength of hardened rubbercrete as CR content increased. However, due to the difficulty in measuring the thickness of the ITZ between the CR particles and the cement matrix, only the thickness of ITZ between the coarse aggregate and the matrix are measured and the results are backed with mercury intrusion porosity (MIP) results for better insight.
The Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) images for the rubbercrete mixtures are shown in Fig. 3. The ITZ between coarse aggregates and thematrix is measured. In normal wet mixtures concrete, ITZ has range from 10 to 50 mm. However, in this investigation, thickness values of ITZ were even lesser due to the fact that the dry rubbercrete mixtures were prepared under high pressure (2500 MPa). As shown in Fig. 4, the thickness of the ITZ increases as the CR contents increases from 0% to 50% which was similar to the observationmade by Li et al. (2016) by using rubber in the form of fiber (Li et al., 2016). This is due to the hydrophobic properties of CR (Gupta et al., 2016). The non-polar layer repels water, and traps air around it, leading to an increase in the air content and consequently increasing the ITZ thickness. However, as the nano silica amount increases, the ITZ thicknesses decrease as shown clearly in Fig. 4. This is owing to the physico-chemical effect of the nano silica. The physical effect is due to the nano size of the particles which can fill up the nano-size porosity of the ITZ, while the chemical effect is due to the pozzolanic effect in which nano silica reacts with the Ca(OH)2 (produced by Portland cement clinker hydration) and produce more CeSeH gel. This leads to densify the ITZ and consequently decrease its thickness (Mukharjee and Barai, 2014a).

sections.heading: 3.3. Mercury Intrusion Porosimetry (MIP)
sections.text:
Usually the solid products of hydration has volume less than the volume of cement and water at 0% of hydration, while the difference in volume is occupied by capillary pores. The nominal diameter size of these pores varies from larger than 1 mm to less than 100 nm. However, if the solid product of hydration is increased it would fill in these capillary pores and subsequently reduced its volume and also breaking up its interconnectivity. Because of the solid products of hydration; which called gel, contains pores due to water evaporation and these pores known as gel pores. These pores are smaller in size compared to capillary pores and have nominal diameter size less than 3 nm. However, gel pores occupy about 28% of the total volume of gel (Neville, 2011). Therefore, due to the size
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),
Fig. 3. ITZ measurements of the rubbercrete mixtures.
of gel pores, only nano particles would be able to physically fill up these pores. The ITZ is a porous phase in the multi-phase concrete (cement, coarse aggregate and ITZ). As mentioned in Section 3.2, the thickness of ITZ could range from 10 to 50 mm. The high porosity of ITZ can be reduced through physico-chemical effects. Whereas,
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
increasing the solid hydration products (gel) and filling up of nano pores would resulting in densifying the ITZ and reducing its pores size. Although no other type of pore exist in the dry rubbercrete mixtures such as pores due to deliberately air entrained and pores due to poor compaction (rubbercrete produced under pressure of
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),
Fig. 5. Porosity versus CR replacement and nano silica inclusion.
Fig. 6. Total pore volume versus CR partial replacement and nano silica addition.
2500 MPa), nevertheless the CR entrapping air into its surface that resulting in a new type of pores. However, these pores can be filled in by the gel.
As shown in Fig. 5, the porosity of the rubbercrete is increased as the percentage of CR replacement increased which is in agreement with the outcome of previous researches (Thomas and Gupta, 2015). This is because the non-polarity of CR that repels water and entraps air on its surface which increases the air voids in the matrix and also increases the pores in the ITZ. However, the porosity of rubbercrete decreases as the nano silica addition increases. Nano silica acts as filler in filling the voids inside thematrix and also induces pozzolanic reaction with portlandite to further filling up the pores present in the ITZ.
In addition, total pores volume of the rubbercrete increases with increasing CR replacement but decreases with increasing addition of nano silica as shown in Fig. 6. This is because increment of CR replacement increases the porosity (Fig. 5) of rubbercrete while the addition of nano silica counters those effects by reducing the porosity of the rubbercrete. In other words, as the total pores
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
volume of rubbercrete increases; the porosity increased and vice versa. This indicated that the pores in the hardened rubbercrete are interconnected and adding the nano silica helps in decreasing the total pore volume and subsequently reducing the porosity.
Figs. 7e10 show pore size distribution for rubbercrete mixtures with NS 0% and different percentage of CR replacement (0%, 10%, 25%, and 50%). The accumulative pore volume increases with increasing CR content. The pore size distribution is ranging from 10 to 100 000 nm in size. However, higher pore volume in the pore size distribution represent that the mixture has higher porosity and permeability as permeability is governed by large capillaries (Li et al., 2016; Du et al., 2014). While Figs. 7 and 11e15 show pore size distribution for CR replacement 0%with different percentage of nano silica from 0% to 5%. The pore diameter also ranges from 10 to 100 000 nm in size. The results showed that the total pore volume decreases with the increasing percentage of nano silica and this is due to the physico-chemical effects of nano silica with the ability to refine the pore structure thus decreasing the total pore volume.
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),

sections.heading: 3.4. Impact resistance
sections.text:
Conventional weight concrete is a rigid brittle material, which is in another words; non-ductile material. This results in low capacity of conventional weight concrete in absorbing energy and resisting repeated impact loading. This set limit to the usage of concrete in some structures requiring high impact resistance and more energy absorption such as road barriers, irrigation structures, structures subjected to high wind gusts and earthquakes, structures subjected to repeated mechanical loads and etc.
Fig. 16 shows the energy absorbed by rubbercrete mixtures. The increasing in the partial replacement of CR resulted in higher impact load absorption capabilities of hardened rubbercrete which is in agreement with finding throughout the literature (Shu and Huang, 2014; Youssf et al., 2014; Segre and Joekes, 2000; Li et al., 2004a). As CR replacement increases from 0% to 50%, the amount of absorbed energy increases from 9.217 kJ to 28.807 kJ at NS0.
Please cite this article in press as: Mohammed, B.S., et al., Properties of na http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2016.02.007
However, as the nano silica inclusion increased from 0% to 5%, the absorbed energy of rubbercrete decreased from 28.807 kJ to 10.875 kJ at CR replacement at 50% for instant. It is worthy of notice that with increasing nano silica inclusion from 3% to 5% and CR replacement from 25% to 50%, the increment in absorbed energy is rather small with an amount of 2.93%.
The direct proportionality tendency between the amount of CR present in the rubbercrete mixture and the impact load energy can be explained by considering rubbercrete has low modulus elasticity. Modulus elasticity of concrete depends on the modulus elasticity of the aggregates and its volume within the concrete (Turatsinzea and Garros, 2008). As the modulus elasticity of CR is lower compared with coarse aggregate, therefore, the modulus elasticity of rubbercrete is lowered with the addition of CR (Pelisser et al., 2011). Addition of CR particles which have low stiffness also increase the flexibility of the rubbercrete allowing it to absorbed more energy compared to reference mix (Mohammed et al., 2011; Gupta et al., 2015). It is worthy of notice that although the CR has been added as partial replacement to fine aggregate, yet it would not be part of the matrix (hardened cement paste: cement, sand and water). However, due to its high elasticity, CR will act like tiny springs inside the microstructure of the hardened rubbercrete. Thus, rubbercrete has the tendency of absorbing more energy from impact load than conventional concrete.
As shown in Fig. 16, absorbing energy is decreased as the amount of nano silica present in the rubbercrete mixtures increasing. This is due to the ability of nano silica in modifying the microstructure of the rubbercrete which leads to increasing the modulus elasticity of rubbercrete (Amin and Abu el-hassan, 2015). Nano silica reacts with portlandite to fill the voids in the rubbercrete including those in the ITZ between aggregate and the cement paste. Consequently, the rubbercrete becomes more compactly dense and homogenous, hence increasing its modulus elasticity causing the ability of rubbercrete in absorbing impact loading to reduce. However, unlike the trend in CR, the continuous increase of nano silica do not seem to reach an asymptotical point, that is, there is a non-stop decrease of the amount of absorbed impact energy when the amount of nano silica is increased. Therefore, an optimum amount of nano silica to be added in a rubbercrete mixture in order to reach optimum absorption capabilities is to be decided in relation with the compressive strength values.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, the compressive, microstructural and impact resistance properties of rubbercrete concrete were investigated. Based on the test results and performed analysis, the following conclusions can be drawn:
1 The compressive strength of rubbercrete is enhanced using nano silica as additives. Therefore, structural rubbercrete; with high CR content, can be produced using rational amount of cement. 2 Inclusion of nano silica in rubbercrete mixtures will enhance the microstructure by refining the pore system and densifying the interfacial transition zone. 3 Reducing total pores volume and porosity of rubbercrete by inclusion of nano silica will enhance its durability. 4 Although inclusion of nano silica in the rubbercrete would sacrifice its higher impact resistance, yet a careful design of these mixtures would yield the desired results in comparison to conventional concrete.
no silica modified rubbercrete, Journal of Cleaner Production (2016),

Globally, more than 500 million units of waste tires were being discarded without any treatment each year after the end of their service life (Thomas et al., 2016).
In addition, these scrap tires are scarcely biodegradable in nature over time and poses a haze danger in case of fire (Pelisser et al., 2011).

Hence, recycling of scrap tires as crumb rubbers (CR) in concrete has become one of alternatives in sustaining the ecological balance with also an added value of economic significant (Guo et al., 2014).

As the modulus elasticity of CR is lower compared with coarse aggregate, therefore, the modulus elasticity of rubbercrete is lowered with the addition of CR (Pelisser et al., 2011).

metadata.abstractText: Inclusion of crumb rubber from scrap tires in concrete as partial replacement to fine aggregate in production of rubbercrete has provided many beneficial impacts to both environments and concrete. Many properties of rubbercrete are improved compared with conventional concrete. However, drawbacks such as reduction in rubbercrete strengths have limited the application of rubbercrete drastically. Therefore, this paper presents a new method on producing rubbercrete with comparable compressive strength to the reference mixture (0% of crumb rubber) by adding nano silica. Twenty four mixtures, with four levels (0%, 10%, 25% and 50%) of crumb rubber replacement to fine aggregate by volume and six levels of nano silica addition (0%, 1%, 2%, 3%, 4% and 5%), were prepared and tested. The microstructure of these mixtures is also investigated and analyzed. It has been found that the inclusion of nano silica would refine the size of the pores and densify the interfacial transition zone between cement matrix and aggregate in hardened rubbercrete. This has resulted rubbercrete with fair compressive strength compared to conventional concrete. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
